discharge_summary: problem: high-risk burkitt-like lymphoma stage iv infiltration mo diagnosis 2020 right neck mass nasopharyngeal renal lesions, cervical lymph node biopsy 05/22: morphological and immunohistochemical picture of b-cell lymphoma, with small, intermediate-sized cells and high proliferative index. immunohistochemistry: positivity for cd20, pax5, weak cd10, bcl6. negativity for cd34, tdt, bcl2, cmyc, ki67 of 95 100%. cd3 evidenced the population of reactive t lymphocytes. cmyc negativity rules out the diagnosis of burkitt's lymphoma. the present case may correspond to burkittlike lymphoma with 11q aberration nasopharyngeal mass biopsy 05/26: b lymphoma with high mitotic index cerebrospinal fluid puncture 06/05: no bmo infiltration 06/03/2020: diffusely infiltrated by b lymphoma with high mitotic index. cd19 / cd 20 / cd10 / bcl 6 if de mo 06/04: cd 19 / cd 20 / cd10 / cd 43 / cd 81 / lambda collection of material for semen cryopreservation 06/05/2020 ecog 0. admission: 13/08/2020, discharge: 08/21/2020, stay: 07 d 22 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma was admitted to the hospital for a second cycle of Rivac D1: 14/08/2020. On 08/16, D3 of the second Rivac, he had a fever peak of 38.1 °C, which lasted for about 1 hour. He reported nausea and had had 3 episodes of bowel movements with softer stools on the day in question. He also had a blood count on the day with 2,000 neutrophils, but already falling, with a tendency towards neutropenia. Given this, the condition was managed as febrile neutropenia, with a probable abdominal focus of infection. It was decided to start cefepime and metronidazole. He underwent a chest CT scan without changes, and a CT scan of the sinuses with evidence of content in the frontal sinus and mastoid. An endoscopic evaluation of the sinuses was performed by [organization], with no evidence of invasive fungal infection. remained on intravenous antibiotic therapy until 08/20, when antibiotic therapy was discussed with [organization], and it was decided to transition to oral clavulin ciprofloxacin. In addition to this, he underwent chemotherapy to date without other complications. He required a transfusion of 1 red blood cell concentrate on 08/19, without complications. Normal physical examination upon discharge. No procedures were performed. Diagnosis already established. 1. I provide folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet, to be taken on 09/01/20 to be taken 24 h after intrathecal chemotherapy 2. I prescribe amoxicillin clavulanate 875 125 mg and ciprofloxacin 500 mg, to be used every 12/12 h, until 8 am on 08/31 3. I prescribe filgrastim for use of 600 mg 2 ampoules in the morning and 300 mg 1 ampoule at night, via subcutaneous application, every day, until the follow-up appointment on 08/27 4. I prescribe prophylaxis: acyclovir 200 mg 2 tablets every 12/12 h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet every 12/12 h on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays omeprazole 20 mg 1 capsule on an empty stomach 5. I prescribe, for use in case of constipation and no bowel movement: lactulose syrup 15 ml every 8 hours, and bisacodyl 5 mg 1 tablet at night. 6. I prescribe ondansetron, in case of nausea or vomiting. 08/25 blood center transfusion room 08/27 outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 08/31 madit outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 09/15 [organization] safety follow-up appointment for clinical reevaluation and check PETCT scheduling counter 6 HC. Good.

question: यह फिलग्रास्टिम मालिया क्या है?
answer: फिलग्रास्टिम एक प्रोटीन है जो ब्लड कोशिकाओं के विकास और वृद्धि में महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका निभाता है। यह मास्टर ट्यूबुलर कोशिकाओं के विकास में भी शामिल है। इसका उपयोग ब्लड कोशिकाओं के विकास को उत्तेजित करने के लिए किया जाता है, जैसे रिकवरी के दौरान ब

discharge_summary: problem: high-risk burkitt-like lymphoma stage iv infiltration mo diagnosis 2020 right neck mass nasopharyngeal renal lesions, cervical lymph node biopsy 05/22: morphological and immunohistochemical picture of b-cell lymphoma, with small, intermediate-sized cells and high proliferative index. immunohistochemistry: positivity for cd20, pax5, weak cd10, bcl6. negativity for cd34, tdt, bcl2, cmyc, ki67 of 95 100%. cd3 evidenced the population of reactive t lymphocytes. cmyc negativity rules out the diagnosis of burkitt's lymphoma. the present case may correspond to burkittlike lymphoma with 11q aberration nasopharyngeal mass biopsy 05/26: b lymphoma with high mitotic index cerebrospinal fluid puncture 06/05: no bmo infiltration 06/03/2020: diffusely infiltrated by b lymphoma with high mitotic index. cd19 / cd 20 / cd10 / bcl 6 if de mo 06/04: cd 19 / cd 20 / cd10 / cd 43 / cd 81 / lambda collection of material for semen cryopreservation 06/05/2020 ecog 0. admission: 13/08/2020, discharge: 08/21/2020, stay: 07 d 22 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma was admitted to the hospital for a second cycle of Rivac D1: 14/08/2020. On 08/16, D3 of the second Rivac, he had a fever peak of 38.1 °C, which lasted for about 1 hour. He reported nausea and had had 3 episodes of bowel movements with softer stools on the day in question. He also had a blood count on the day with 2,000 neutrophils, but already falling, with a tendency towards neutropenia. Given this, the condition was managed as febrile neutropenia, with a probable abdominal focus of infection. It was decided to start cefepime and metronidazole. He underwent a chest CT scan without changes, and a CT scan of the sinuses with evidence of content in the frontal sinus and mastoid. An endoscopic evaluation of the sinuses was performed by [organization], with no evidence of invasive fungal infection. remained on intravenous antibiotic therapy until 08/20, when antibiotic therapy was discussed with [organization], and it was decided to transition to oral clavulin ciprofloxacin. In addition to this, he underwent chemotherapy to date without other complications. He required a transfusion of 1 red blood cell concentrate on 08/19, without complications. Normal physical examination upon discharge. No procedures were performed. Diagnosis already established. 1. I provide folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet, to be taken on 09/01/20 to be taken 24 h after intrathecal chemotherapy 2. I prescribe amoxicillin clavulanate 875 125 mg and ciprofloxacin 500 mg, to be used every 12/12 h, until 8 am on 08/31 3. I prescribe filgrastim for use of 600 mg 2 ampoules in the morning and 300 mg 1 ampoule at night, via subcutaneous application, every day, until the follow-up appointment on 08/27 4. I prescribe prophylaxis: acyclovir 200 mg 2 tablets every 12/12 h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet every 12/12 h on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays omeprazole 20 mg 1 capsule on an empty stomach 5. I prescribe, for use in case of constipation and no bowel movement: lactulose syrup 15 ml every 8 hours, and bisacodyl 5 mg 1 tablet at night. 6. I prescribe ondansetron, in case of nausea or vomiting. 08/25 blood center transfusion room 08/27 outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 08/31 madit outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 09/15 [organization] safety follow-up appointment for clinical reevaluation and check PETCT scheduling counter 6 HC. Good.
question: 15 सितंबर को मेरे दाखिले का उद्देश्य क्या है?
answer: To initiate chemotherapy for the treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma.

discharge_summary: admission: 10/06/2020, discharge: 11/20/2020, stay: 01 m 13 d 19 h, location: ward, payer: sus. discharge report patient [person], 54 years old, single, from [address], receives retirement benefit, admitted to the emergency unit of [organization] on 10/06 with dyspnea 8 days after admission, fever not measured and cough with greenish sputum. on 10/08, he presented respiratory failure, requiring orotracheal intubation and high oxygen concentrations pao2/fio2 ratio: 104, with neuromuscular blockade for ventilation for sara. On 10/9, due to oliguria in the last 24 hours, however, maintaining a positive fluid balance, he was transferred to the semi-intensive care unit without the use of vasoactive drugs due to the hypothesis of nephrotoxicity. On 10/10, vasoactive drugs were restarted due to poor peripheral perfusion. Neuromuscular blockade with cisatracurium was suspended. [person] developed abdominal distension, with suspension of the diet. On 10/14, an abdominal ultrasound was performed with no signs of ascites or gaseous distension. On 10/15, sedation was suspended. On the same day, [person] presented with a deviation of the fixed gaze to the right, being evaluated by neurology and, after a computed tomography scan of the skull and electroencephalogram, without new alterations that would justify the condition, vitamin B1 replacement was indicated. On 10/19, a thoracic ultrasound was performed, showing evidence of pleural effusion on the left, measuring approximately 3.3 cm. Diagnostic thoracentesis was performed, with negative transudate culture and bacilloscopy, but with positive TBTRM on 10/22. At the time, a case of ICC was discussed, and as [person] did not present a picture suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis upon admission, with no characteristic image, remaining afebrile throughout hospitalization, with progressive improvement of the pulmonary condition with Bactrim, in addition to 3 negative gastric lavage bacilloscopy samples in August of that year, it was decided not to isolate [person] and not to collect bacilloscopy again, since the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis was very unlikely. On 10/22, extubation was performed, without complications. On 10/23, [person] presented diarrhea, with liquid stools, no pathological products and no other systemic symptoms. On 10/25, he started a soft oral diet with good acceptance, and the nasogastric tube was removed and treatment for pleural tuberculosis was initiated by the attending medical team. On 10/26, [person] was admitted to a bed in the [organization] ward and, on 10/29, transferred to a bed in the [organization] ward, under the care of the infectious disease team. On 10/28, treatment for pneumocystosis with Bactrim D21/D21 was suspended and corticosteroid therapy was suspended, with Bactrim being resumed at a prophylactic dose for neurotoxoplasmosis and pneumocystosis. During hospitalization, [person] presented persistent thrombocytopenia while on prophylactic anticoagulation. Hematology assessed him and indicated the start of full-dose subcutaneous fondaparinoux 7.5 mg. On 11/3, with a platelet count above 150,000, dual anticoagulation with warfarin 5 mg/day was initiated. maintained until 11/08, with warfarin adjustment according to prothrombin time, due to anticoagulation for 4 weeks. In addition, [person] presented anemia probably secondary to azathioprine myelotoxicity and vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 replacement was started, 1 vial of 5000 mcg 1x per week. Upon admission to the [organization] ward, it was decided to suspend the RIP regimen due to an acute clinical laboratory picture not compatible with pulmonary or pleural tuberculosis. [person] presented infectious urinalysis culture positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, but as he remained asymptomatic and with good renal function, it was decided not to treat it, considering contamination. [person] is currently fit for hospital discharge, being on room air, with no signs of discomfort, hemodynamically stable, not using vasoactive drugs, and with good acceptance of oral diet, assisted only by the risk of bronchoaspiration, with international normalized ratio in the range of 2.9 with 5 mg of warfarin/day. Current problem 1. Nosocomial pneumonia? Recent admission to [organization] 08/14 09/25 Community-acquired pneumonia treated with clavulin, pcp Presumed hepatotoxicity due to bactrin Nosocomial pneumonia treated with cefepime 2. Pneumocystosis? 3. Normochromic macrocytic anemia to be clarified secondary to bactrim? Secondary to zidovudine? 4. Thrombocytopenia to be clarified Thrombocytopenia induced by prophylactic heparin? Tests 1. Transthoracic echocardiography 08/17: cardiac chambers with normal dimensions. left ventricular systolic performance and segmental mobility were normal. 2. abdominal ultrasound 8/17: ultrasound signs that may correspond to liver disease, with no evidence of suspicious focal lesions. absence of free intra-abdominal fluid. problem: 1. human immunodeficiency virus c3 diagnosed in 2004 8/17: cd4 135/cv: undetectable 2. neurotoxoplasmosis with motor sequelae in the right upper limb 3. anti hcv / hcv pcr negative 4. neurological disorder to be clarified wernicke's encephalopathy? psychiatric disorder to be clarified 5. chronic liver disease diagnosed in 2016 6. presumed chronic obstructive pulmonary disease medications in use risperidone 2 mg at night warfarin 5 mg/day until 12/01 discontinue after antiretroviral therapy: tenofovir 300 mg lamivudine 300 mg 1 tablet early darunavir 600 mg 1 tablet 12/12h ritonavir 100 mg 1 tablet 12/12h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet 12/12h pcp prophylaxis and neurotoxicity folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet/day. no changes.. programming we consider anemia secondary to probable myelotoxicity due to antiretroviral therapy AZT being replaced by tenofovir on 11/09. I maintain prophylaxis for PCP and neurotox with Bactrim, maintain folinic acid replacement 15 mg/day until follow-up appointment, decided to suspend vitamin B12 replacement, given 2 recent dosages with normal vitamin B12, maintain anticoagulation with warfarin started on 11/03 for 4 weeks until 12/01. follow-up appointment to the outpatient clinic, request tests for follow-up appointment. Good.
question: मैं कब से अस्पताल में हूँ?
answer:
10/06/2020

### Explanation:
The discharge letter states that the patient was admitted to the emergency unit of [organization] on 10/06/2020. Therefore, the patient has been in the hospital since 10/06/2020. The answer is straightforward and directly taken from the discharge letter. No additional information is needed.

question: The monkey said his TB test was positive, but later said it wasn't. I think I have TB too.
answer: No, you do not have TB. The discharge letter states that the patient had a positive TB test on 10/22, but later it was determined that the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis was unlikely. The patient was not isolated and no further testing was performed. The current problem states that the patient has a negative TB test result. The monkey's statement is not relevant to the patient's actual medical condition. The patient's TB test was positive initially, but the diagnosis was later deemed unlikely, and the patient was not isolated. The patient's current TB test result is negative. Therefore, the patient does not have TB. The monkey's statement

question: क्या मुझे बिना खून के वारफेरिन का उपयोग करना चाहिए?
answer: No, you should not use warfarin without blood tests. The discharge letter states that [person] is currently on warfarin 5 mg/day, which is being maintained until 12/01. The letter also mentions that warfarin adjustment is being done according to prothrombin time due to anticoagulation for 4 weeks. However, it does not explicitly state that warfarin should not be used without blood tests. But, in general, warfarin should be monitored with regular blood tests to ensure it is working properly and to avoid bleeding complications. Therefore, it is recommended to continue monitoring with regular

[person] attends hemodialysis session with severe left lower back pain that had started 3 days ago, associated with asthenia, and altered gait. [person] who was accompanying him, denies fever, nausea, and vomiting. Denies other associated symptoms. catheter dressing in the right femoral vein was secreting. [person] evolved during hospitalization with a diagnosis of bloodstream infection by staphylococcus aureus mrsa, complicated by l2l4 spondylodiscitis, mitral valve infective endocarditis, and ileopsoas muscle abscess. Catheter removed on 11/08 and antibiotic therapy guided by vancomycin culture was started on 11/08. Abscess in psoas was not approached due to interposition of bowel loops in an attempt at percutaneous drainage by the {organization} on 12/02. Comparative radiological improvement was observed in axial lesions and conservative treatment was maintained regarding foci of infection identified during hospitalization. [person] remained afebrile with successively negative blood cultures. As a complication associated with immobility, he developed sacral pressure injury, treated with surgical debridement and local measures. Injury care guidelines were provided by the team. He evolved with the need for hemodialysis on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays due to arteriovenous fistula in the left upper limb, but local stenosis was noted. He is currently on renal replacement therapy. good general condition, pale 1/4, hydrated, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile to the touch and eupneic in room air. neurology: conscious and oriented in time, space and person. respiratory auscultation: bilateral vesicular breath sounds with discreet bibasilar crackles, no signs of respiratory distress. cardiac auscultation: irregular heart rhythm, with normal sound sounds, no murmurs. abdomen: protuberant, bowel sounds, normotensive, painless on superficial or deep palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation. warm and well perfused extremities. upper limbs: fistula in the left upper limb with present thrill. lower limbs: presence of discreet edema and anterior tibial ochre dermatitis. nuclear magnetic resonance 25/10/2020: discharge_summary: coronavirus . admission: 2020-03-15, discharge: 2020-05-11, stay: 01 m 25 d 17 h, location: ward, payer: sus. id: [person], 59 years old, from [address] patient admitted on 2020-03-15 to the emergency unit of [organization] due to severe acute respiratory syndrome caused by coronavirus. patient in need of orotracheal intubation since 2020-03-17 with progression to tracheostomy on 2020-04-08. evolved with improvement in respiratory parameters being decannulated on 2020-05-08, remaining without tracheostomy, without respiratory discomfort, only with occlusive dressing. presented several complications during hospitalization, such as: 1 low-embolic load pulmonary thromboembolism, examination described below; 2 pulmonary septic shock with carbapenem-sensitive Acinetobacter baumannii, being treated with meropnem and polymyxin for 10 days and subsequently using tigecycline for 14 days, with improvement in the condition; 3 acute kidney injury, code 3, without the need for dialysis with subsequent reversal; 4 primary bloodstream infection secondary to Burkholderia cepacia, sensitive to ceftazidime and Bactrim. evolved with rehabilitation with motor and respiratory physiotherapy, with good tolerance and improved functionality during hospitalization. [person] without the need for oxygen therapy for more than 48 hours, with the need to consolidate treatment for bloodstream infection with oral Bactrim. opted for hospital discharge after a long period of hospitalization with improvement in the coronavirus condition and hospital complications. described below is the schedule for ending treatment for [person] after discharge. good general condition, pale 2/4, hydrated, oriented in time and space, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, eupneic heart rate: 70 oxygen saturation: 98% in room air cardiac auscultation: heart rhythm in normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, normal heart sounds, preserved capillary refill time, absence of jugular distension at 90º respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds present, no adventitious sounds, absence of use of accessory respiratory muscles abdomen: flaccid, painless, bowel sounds present and normal, tympanic to percussion, no palpable masses or palpable visceromegaly extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, well perfused extremities, absence of edema in the lower limbs, absence of signs of deep vein thrombosis neurology: Glasgow Coma Scale 15, presence of tremor postural in upper limbs. coronavirus pulmonary thromboembolism. schedule: anticoagulation for 6 months counting the start of treatment from 03/31/2020 ending on 09/31/2020 at the moment there is a need to use rivaroxaban 15 mg 12/12 h for another 7 days after discharge and subsequently use of a dose of rivaroxaban 20 mg/day until 05/07/2020. end of treatment for bloodstream infection with bactrin 2 tablets 8/8 hours for another 5 days after hospital discharge requested maintenance of respiratory and motor physiotherapy in [person's] city of origin. hospitalization exams: chest CT Angiography (CTA) 03/31: acute pulmonary thromboembolism with low embolic burden, without cor pulmonale. opacities compatible with coronavirus, severe involvement 50 - 75% with a component of organizing pneumonia and fibroreaction. cardiomegaly. Transthoracic echocardiography 07/05: ejection fraction 57%, mild dilation of the left atrium, preserved systolic performance of the right and left ventricles, without images suggestive of vegetation. discharge with follow-up in primary care. good conditions for hospital discharge.

discharge_summary: admission: 05/28/2020, discharge: 06/06/2020, stay: 09 d 04 h, location: ward, payer: sus. identification: [person], 80 years old, from [address], social worker, retired, married. problem: 1 sepsis of pulmonary focus treated with ceftriaxone d10 clarithromycin d8 pulmonary focus: productive cough flu-like symptoms fever dyspnea desaturation 6 days ago acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creat 2.14 / basal 0.68 discharged from nephrology on 06/05. hypotension requiring norepinephrine. 2 atrial fibrillation with high ventricular response 05/28 reversed amiodarone chads2vas 4. 3 urinary tract infection candida treated with fluconazole. History of current illness: Patient with previous chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, under treatment with anoro umeclidino vilanterol, with a history of smoking, discontinued in 1988 53 pack-years. Reports that 6 days ago he started having a productive cough, associated with runny nose, nasal obstruction and shortness of breath, as well as a fever of 38 ºC in the first 3 days of symptoms. 3 days ago, he had an appointment with a pulmonologist, and was started on oseltamivir every 12 hours, but for the past 1 day he has been developing worsening shortness of breath, ventilatory-dependent pain in the back and lung bases, as well as a decline in general condition. Reports having taken tests for coronavirus and influenza, both negative. Denies gastrointestinal and genitourinary complaints. No other complaints. Personal history: 1. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (IPD)? Aspiration?? Spirometry 2019: obstruction with FEV1 31.59%, FVC 63.9%, no response to bronchodilator. Chest computed tomography 2021: emphysema, reticular infiltrate without honeycombing in the right base. Aspiration? 2. Systemic arterial hypertension 3. Diabetes mellitus 4. Hypothyroidism 5. Depressive disorder under current treatment. 6. Hearing impairment under treatment with a hearing aid. Continuous-use medications: Anoro, Metformin 1000 mg/day, Dapagliflozin 10 mg, Escitalopram 10 mg, Puran T 125 mcg, Rosuvastatin 5 mg, Calcium carbonate 1000 mg/day, Vit D3 1000 IU/day. Allergies: Denies. Surgeries: Denies. habits and addictions: denies alcoholism, smoking 52 pack-years; quit in 1988. antibiotic therapy ceftriaxone 1g 12/12h 05/28 06/06 clarithromycin 500 mg 12/12h 05/28 05/06 fluconazole 05/31 06/06. tests: transthoracic echocardiography 05/30/2020: mild left atrial dilation. concentric left ventricular remodeling, preserved systolic performance of the ventricles. normal left ventricular segmental mobility. mild mac mitral annular calcification. mild mitral and ai. clinical evolution [organization] finds [person] in a ward bed accompanied by [person]. hemodynamically stable, using a central venous catheter, no vasoactive drugs, and an indwelling urinary catheter. [person] reports improvement in respiratory condition, with reduction in fatigue and inspiratory pain and improvement in cough in appearance and volume, but reports that dyspnea persists with minimal effort such as taking a bath. Reports regular use of alenia, without use of supplemental oxygen, eupneic in room air, presents improvement in respiratory pattern. Reports anal pain, with presence of prolapsed hemorrhoid. Reports daily bowel movements, of liquid pasty consistency, without pain or effort. Reports bedsore in gluteal region without pain symptoms, reported by nursing and {person}. Discussed during visit with [person]: [person] with pneumococcus intermediate to ceftriaxone, however, given clinical and laboratory improvement, weaning from oxygen, maintaining cough, improving, we recommend hospital discharge. I keep [person] aware that in the event of further clinical worsening, he should seek emergency unit for reevaluation. [person] did not present recurrence of atrial fibrillation with high ventricular response; however, due to CHADs2 of 4, with a high risk of recurrence, seen in transthoracic echocardiography with atrial enlargement, we maintained rhythm control with amiodarone 200 mg 12/12h and started anticoagulation with rivaroxaban 20 mg/day. In addition, during hospitalization, he presented worsening of hemorrhoidal disease, now prolapsed, on local conservative therapy. Upon discharge, we requested a control electrocardiogram, laboratory tests for follow-up, scheduled to be performed on 06/27 with teleconsultation on 06/28. prescription at discharge: amiodarone 200 mg 12/12h rivaroxaban 20 mg/day amlodipine 5 mg 12/12h levothyroxine 125 mcg/day rosuvastatin 5 mg/day escitalopram 10 mg/day metformin xr 1g/day dapagliflozin 10 mg/day anoro 1 spray per day salbutamol sn proctyl ointment. follow-up: teleconsultation with geriatrics on 06/28 in the afternoon. good general condition, conscious, oriented, eupneic in room air, no pain complaints, with clinical improvement and recovery of renal function.

discharge_summary: admission: 12/11/2020, discharge: 01/23/2021, stay: 01 m 11 d 10 h, location: ward, payer: sus [person], 28 years old, from [address] 12/14 weight: 102 kg height: 162 cm. problem: 1 Status epilepticus secondary to pulmonary infection Phenytoin attack performed and maintenance dose of PHT increased Pb dosage maintained Dosage of other drugs LTG, TPM and CLB 2 Sepsis pulmonary focus 3 Deep vein thrombosis Right lower limb Full dose of enoxaparin started on 12/23 4 Pseudomembranous colitis Metronidazole started 12/30 01/10 5 Adrenal insufficiency secondary to sepsis Hydrocortisone 50 mg every 12h started on 12/31 Weaning started on 01/10 Previous functionality Oral diet Walked without assistance Dependent for some instrumental activities of daily living Bathing, physiological eliminations. Tests: Electroencephalogram 12/12: Mild to moderate disorganization of baseline activity due to increased slow wave content in the theta and delta bands, but with the presence of normal sleep graphoelements. There was no clinical or electrographic reactivity to nociceptive stimulation. b Record of electrographic seizures of variable duration (4 to 9 seconds), characterized by rhythmic activity in the beta range, evolving to alpha and theta ranges, associated with spike-type epileptiform paroxysms, with generalized projection, without associated clinical phenomena. There was a record of a seizure with rhythmic evolution to the delta range and of longer duration (18 seconds). Rare spike-type paroxysms were recorded, occurring isolatedly in the left frontocentral region. Clinical correlation: The findings are consistent with focal epilepsy with electrographic seizures, but do not characterize status epilepticus. electroencephalogram 12/19: marked symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to persistent rhythmic, semi-rhythmic bifrontal slowing in the delta band, at approximately 1.5 Hz, of medium amplitude, only temporarily mitigated by nociceptive stimulation; furthermore, lack and poor definition of physiological graphoelements of sleep. Upon nociceptive stimulation, there is also a triggering of generalized rhythmic epileptiform activity in the beta band, of low voltage, which evolves into an outbreak of frank epileptiform paroxysms of the spike type followed by a slow wave, also of diffuse expression, and with bifrontal accentuation of such stimulus-induced discharges, suppression of the clinical tracing follows; [person] presents only with painful facies. b Occasionally, associated with the slow waves described above, bisynchronous epileptiform paroxysms of the sharp wave type are observed, involving the anterior regions of the scalp. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with severe diffuse encephalopathy of a nonspecific nature, associated with focal and generalized interictal epileptogenesis, the latter being stimulus-induced. Electroencephalogram 12/22: a moderate symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to an increase in the content of slow waves in the theta and delta bands, in addition to a lack and poor definition of the physiological graphoelements of sleep. However, good electroencephalographic reactivity is noted in response to nociceptive stimuli, with an association with a dominant posterior rhythmic outline in the alpha band. b bursts of generalized rhythmic delta activity (grda) with bifrontal accentuation, occurring intermittently throughout the tracing during sleep, consisting of stereotyped waves in the 2.0 to 2.5 Hz band. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with moderate diffuse encephalopathy, of a nonspecific nature in relation to the previous tracing; significant improvement is noted, with mitigation of grda and suppression of stimulus-induced generalized epileptogenesis. electroencephalogram 02/01: slight symmetrical disorganization of the baseline activity due to the slowing of the dominant posterior rhythm of wakefulness, recorded at a frequency of up to 6.5 Hz, however with the presence of typical physiological graphoelements of sleep. b recording of epileptiform paroxysms of the spike and sharp wave type, with generalized projection, with anterior accentuation, occurring in rhythmic bursts of short duration of 3 to 4 seconds. the paroxysms are followed by delta waves and, occasionally, rhythmic activity in the beta range of short duration of less than 1 second, which also occurred preceding the bursts of paroxysms, as well as in an isolated episode during drowsiness. c outbreaks of generalized delta activity, with bifrontal accentuation, the same projections as the paroxysms, also occurring exclusively during sleep. note: [person] presented stereotyped cephalic lateralization and oromandibular movements during wakefulness, however, without electrographic correlation with ictal patterns. conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. the findings are compatible with diffuse encephalopathy and generalized epilepsy. computed tomography of the skull 11/12: no relevant alterations; computed tomography of the chest 11/12: no signs of an infectious process; cerebrospinal fluid 13/12: 1 cell; 0 red blood cells; glucose: 96; protein: non-reactive; chloride: 125; lactate: 1.91; transthoracic echocardiography 23/12: no signs of vegetation. no other alterations. cultures: tracheal aspirate: 12/27: enterobacter cloacae complex sensitive to meropenem 12/19: negative 12/12: staphylococcus aureus oxas resistant to clindamycin 01/07: staphylococcus epidermididis oxar blood culture: 12/27: negative so far 12/19: staphylococcus hominis 12/13: negative 01/07: 01/16: pseudomonas aeroginosas sensitive to ciprofloxacin, cephalosporin and aminoglycoside urine culture: 12/27: negative 01/07: negative venous catheter: 12/27: negative 12/19: corynebacterium sensitive to vancomycin and teicoplanin 01/09: staphylococcus epidermidis oxar cerebrospinal fluid: 12/13: micrococcus sp antibiotic therapy: current: ceftazidime d0 01/19 pseudomonas bloodstream infection. AEDC follow-up appointments: 02/02 schedule to complete antibiotic therapy directed at pseudomonas bloodstream infection: using ceftazidime d3, maintain for 7-10 days: currently clinically stable, cpr falling, last 2.5 AEDC: 02/02/22 maintain current antiepileptic drugs until follow-up appointment: phenytoin 100 mg 12/12h phenobarbital 100 mg 12/12h topiramate 100 100 200 clobazam 20 mg 8/8h lamotrigine 100 100 200 I renew prescriptions from [organization] regarding deep vein thrombosis: I prescribe rivaroxaban 20 mg/d, I provide a prescription for 6 months. I request follow-up in the network. Follow-up by physiotherapy at the CER: difficulty walking, associated with equine feet. Wheelchair, bath and diaper report: already delivered. Treatment for scabies with ivermectin was carried out on 01/17, repeat in 7 days. Regular general condition, acyanotic, anicteric, hydrated, afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in 2t, normal sound sounds, no audible murmurs. Respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds in both hemithorax, no adventitious sounds. Globular abdomen, bowel sounds, depressed and no signs of defense. Warm extremities, capillary refill time less than 3s, free calves Glasgow 14, isochoric and photoreactive pupils, no pupillary hippus, no stigmata of crisis. Can raise all 4 limbs and hold them against gravity. Understands and obeys commands. Equine feet bilaterally.
question: What real problems did I face in the hospital?
answer: I faced status epilepticus, sepsis, deep vein thrombosis, pseudomembranous colitis, and adrenal insufficiency.

There was no clinical or electrographic reactivity to nociceptive stimulation. b Record of electrographic seizures of variable duration (4 to 9 seconds), characterized by rhythmic activity in the beta range, evolving to alpha and theta ranges, associated with spike-type epileptiform paroxysms, with generalized projection, without associated clinical phenomena. There was a record of a seizure with rhythmic evolution to the delta range and of longer duration (18 seconds). Rare spike-type paroxysms were recorded, occurring isolatedly in the left frontocentral region. Clinical correlation: The findings are consistent with focal epilepsy with electrographic seizures, but do not characterize status epilepticus. electroencephalogram 12/19: marked symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to persistent rhythmic, semi-rhythmic bifrontal slowing in the delta band, at approximately 1.5 Hz, of medium amplitude, only temporarily mitigated by nociceptive stimulation; furthermore, lack and poor definition of physiological graphoelements of sleep. Upon nociceptive stimulation, there is also a triggering of generalized rhythmic epileptiform activity in the beta band, of low voltage, which evolves into an outbreak of frank epileptiform paroxysms of the spike type followed by a slow wave, also of diffuse expression, and with bifrontal accentuation of such stimulus-induced discharges, suppression of the clinical tracing follows; [person] presents only with painful facies. b Occasionally, associated with the slow waves described above, bisynchronous epileptiform paroxysms of the sharp wave type are observed, involving the anterior regions of the scalp. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with severe diffuse encephalopathy of a nonspecific nature, associated with focal and generalized interictal epileptogenesis, the latter being stimulus-induced. Electroencephalogram 12/22: a moderate symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to an increase in the content of slow waves in the theta and delta bands, in addition to a lack and poor definition of the physiological graphoelements of sleep. However, good electroencephalographic reactivity is noted in response to nociceptive stimuli, with an association with a dominant posterior rhythmic outline in the alpha band. b bursts of generalized rhythmic delta activity (grda) with bifrontal accentuation, occurring intermittently throughout the tracing during sleep, consisting of stereotyped waves in the 2.0 to 2.5 Hz band. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with moderate diffuse encephalopathy, of a nonspecific nature in relation to the previous tracing; significant improvement is noted, with mitigation of grda and suppression of stimulus-induced generalized epileptogenesis. electroencephalogram 02/01: slight symmetrical disorganization of the baseline activity due to the slowing of the dominant posterior rhythm of wakefulness, recorded at a frequency of up to 6.5 Hz, however with the presence of typical physiological graphoelements of sleep. b recording of epileptiform paroxysms of the spike and sharp wave type, with generalized projection, with anterior accentuation, occurring in rhythmic bursts of short duration of 3 to 4 seconds. the paroxysms are followed by delta waves and, occasionally, rhythmic activity in the beta range of short duration of less than 1 second, which also occurred preceding the bursts of paroxysms, as well as in an isolated episode during drowsiness. c outbreaks of generalized delta activity, with bifrontal accentuation, the same projections as the paroxysms, also occurring exclusively during sleep. note: [person] presented stereotyped cephalic lateralization and oromandibular movements during wakefulness, however, without electrographic correlation with ictal patterns. conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. the findings are compatible with diffuse encephalopathy and generalized epilepsy. computed tomography of the skull 11/12: no relevant alterations; computed tomography of the chest 11/12: no signs of an infectious process; cerebrospinal fluid 13/12: 1 cell; 0 red blood cells; glucose: 96; protein: non-reactive; chloride: 125; lactate: 1.91; transthoracic echocardiography 23/12: no signs of vegetation. no other alterations. cultures: tracheal aspirate: 12/27: enterobacter cloacae complex sensitive to meropenem 12/19: negative 12/12: staphylococcus aureus oxas resistant to clindamycin 01/07: staphylococcus epidermididis oxar blood culture: 12/27: negative so far 12/19: staphylococcus hominis 12/13: negative 01/07: 01/16: pseudomonas aeroginosas sensitive to ciprofloxacin, cephalosporin and aminoglycoside urine culture: 12/27: negative 01/07: negative venous catheter: 12/27: negative 12/19: corynebacterium sensitive to vancomycin and teicoplanin 01/09: staphylococcus epidermidis oxar cerebrospinal fluid: 12/13: micrococcus sp antibiotic therapy: current: ceftazidime d0 01/19 pseudomonas bloodstream infection. AEDC follow-up appointments: 02/02 schedule to complete antibiotic therapy directed at pseudomonas bloodstream infection: using ceftazidime d3, maintain for 7-10 days: currently clinically stable, cpr falling, last 2.5 AEDC: 02/02/22 maintain current antiepileptic drugs until follow-up appointment: phenytoin 100 mg 12/12h phenobarbital 100 mg 12/12h topiramate 100 100 200 clobazam 20 mg 8/8h lamotrigine 100 100 200 I renew prescriptions from [organization] regarding deep vein thrombosis: I prescribe rivaroxaban 20 mg/d, I provide a prescription for 6 months. I request follow-up in the network. Follow-up by physiotherapy at the CER: difficulty walking, associated with equine feet. Wheelchair, bath and diaper report: already delivered. Treatment for scabies with ivermectin was carried out on 01/17, repeat in 7 days. Regular general condition, acyanotic, anicteric, hydrated, afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in 2t, normal sound sounds, no audible murmurs. Respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds in both hemithorax, no adventitious sounds. Globular abdomen, bowel sounds, depressed and no signs of defense. Warm extremities, capillary refill time less than 3s, free calves Glasgow 14, isochoric and photoreactive pupils, no pupillary hippus, no stigmata of crisis. Can raise all 4 limbs and hold them against gravity. Understands and obeys commands. Equine feet bilaterally.
question: क्या मुझे सेफ़्टाज़िडाइम एंटीबायोटिक लेनी चाहिए?
answer: Yes, you should continue taking cefazimic as per the discharge letter instructions. The discharge letter states to maintain cefazimid for 7-10 days to treat pseudomonas bloodstream infection.

question: मुझे आश्चर्य है कि किस प्रकार की पनीर वाली दवाएँ उपयोग में हैं?

question: क्या मुझे किसी फिजियोथेरेपिस्ट से मिलना चाहिए?
answer: Yes, you should see a physiotherapist. The discharge letter mentions difficulty walking and the need for a wheelchair, bath, and diaper report. The patient is also being followed by a physiotherapist at the CER.

answer: Yes, scabies can be treated with ivermectin. The patient was treated with ivermectin on 01/17 and a repeat is scheduled for 01/24.

question: What will I do when I get out of the hospital?
answer: I will continue to take phenytoin, phenobarbital, topiramate, clobazam, and lamotrigine as prescribed. I will also take rivaroxaban for deep vein thrombosis. I will follow up with a physiotherapist at the CER for my equine feet. I will continue with the treatment for scabies with ivermectin. I will maintain regular general condition, acyanotic, anicteric, hydrated, afebrile. I will continue with cardiac auscultation, respiratory auscultation, and physical examination. Warm extremities, capillary refill time less than 3s, free calves Glasgow 14, isochoric and photoreactive pupils, no pupillary hippus, no stigmata of crisis. Can raise all 4 limbs and hold them against gravity. Understands and obeys commands. Equine feet bilaterally.

07/31/2020 vi vtd d1 10/07/2020 to d1 03/10/2021 while awaiting krd disease progression previous therapeutic schedule krd total of xviii cycles [person]: performed v cycles, with disease progression during hospitalization: head tomography 05/10 done in the context of lowered level of consciousness, thrombocytopenia, bleeding ruled out. transthoracic echocardiography 10/08: preserved LVSD subjective s 8 pp 8 LVDD 45 it mild psap 50 mmhg rectification of the septum in the shape of a d extracardiac structure compressing the left atrium moderately depressed RVSD fac 20% transthoracic echocardiography 10/19: fe 62% LVDD 46 s 9.5 pp 9 filamentous images adhered to the atrial face measuring the largest 4 mm suggestive of mild IM vegetation, cultures: blood culture 10/04: I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. I prescribe SLOK K 1 tablet every 12 hours. Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

discharge_summary: admission: 09/01/2020, discharge: 09/17/2020, stay: 16 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: SUS. A 67-year-old patient with a history of overweight, smoking, and major depression was admitted on 09/01 with a perforative acute abdomen, diagnosed after examinations. On the evening of 08/31, she sought care with abdominal pain, general malaise, and dyspnea. She had undergone hysterectomy on 08/30. On 09/01, she underwent exploratory laparotomy with a finding of intestinal perforation, with a suture of the lesion and placement of a peritoneostomy. She developed severe circulatory shock, probably due to peritonitis from contamination of the abdominal cavity, and antibiotic treatment was promptly started. She was re-addressed on 09/06, where an appendectomy and abdominal wall closure were performed. On 09/07, the patient's ventilatory status began to worsen, and a chest tomography scan was performed on 09/08, revealing low-load pulmonary embolism (5%) in addition to pneumonia. A multiresistant germ was isolated in a lung culture, with specific treatment directed at the patient. Given the clinical progression, a tracheostomy was indicated due to the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. On 09/15, {omitted} prolonged cardiopulmonary arrest was reversed after approximately 20 minutes. The patient follow-up appointmented to the intensive care unit after the procedure, with mydriatic pupils and absence of reflexes. On 09/17, a computed tomography scan of the skull was performed, revealing anoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Tests were performed to confirm brain death, which was confirmed on {omitted}. Perforating acute abdomen. 09/01: computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis: pneumoperitoneum, ascites, signs of peritonitis, parietal hyperalces and edema of the loops 09/01: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly, bilateral pleural effusion, opacities suggestive of an inflammatory or infectious process 09/08: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary thromboembolism with 5% embolic burden 09/17: computed tomography of the skull. 09/01: exploratory laparotomy, sigmoid suture, creation of peritoneostomy 09/06: review, touch-ups on previous surgery with appendectomy and closure of the abdominal wall 09/15: tracheostomy 09/15: bilateral chest drainage. death.

discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

question: 'न्यूमेडियास्टिनेनम' का क्या अर्थ है?
answer: न्यूमेडियास्टिनेनम (Pneumomediastinum) एक पल्मोनरी स्थिति है जिसमें साँस के प्रवाह के कारण मीडियस्टीन (मीडियस्टीन) में हवा का जमाव होता है। यह आमतौर पर आंत्रिक संचार के कारण होता है, जैसे कि आंत्रिक संचार के दौरान हवा के प्रवाह से मीडियस्टीन

On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. ExtremITIES: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

answer: Yes, I went into tracheostomy.

question: क्या मुझे खून पतला करने वाली दवा (नोक्सोपैरिन) बंद करनी होगी?
answer:

discharge_summary: 1. coronavirus infection onset of symptoms 02/17 orotracheal intubation 02/24 extubation 03/08 2. septic shock from pulmonary focus requiring vasoactive drug resolved: antibiotic therapy: ceftriaxone 02/23 03/02 clarithromycin 04/24 03/02 corticosteroid therapy: 02/24 03/09 3. critically ill polyneuropathy grade 2 strength upper limbs and lower limbs 4. pressure injury left lower limb grade i 5. your appointment scheduled with gynecology. on 03/24 for investigation. admission: 02/24/2020, discharge: 03/19/2020, stay: 22 d 21 h, location: ward, payer: sus. current: [person] with severe acute respiratory syndrome due to coronavirus, onset of symptoms on 02/17, requiring orotracheal intubation due to respiratory failure on 02/24, due to the possibility of associated bacterial pneumonia, antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and clarithromycin was performed. [person] presented satisfactory clinical evolution, and extubation was performed on 03/08, without complications. Gradual weaning of oxygen therapy was performed, and oxygen was withdrawn on 03/17, at the time comfortable in room air. Due to prolonged use of neuromuscular blocker to manage mechanical ventilation, [person] developed critically ill polyneuropathy, currently with grade II motor strength in the upper and lower limbs. He also has a pressure injury in the left lower limb, which is improving, with no signs of infection. Insulin therapy was started to manage hyperglycemia, with weaning after optimization of oral metformin. It is worth mentioning that during hospitalization [person] presented abnormal vaginal bleeding, and an appointment with gynecology was scheduled for 03/24 for investigation. Good general condition, hydrated, normal color, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile; respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds with crackles on a residual basis, without respiratory distress; cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in two beats; normal sound sounds without murmurs; abdomen: innocent; extremities without edema, free calves, capillary refill time less than 3 s, ulcer on the left lower limb, grade I. therapeutic plan: I speak with [person] about the importance of performing pulmonary and motor physiotherapy to manage polyneuropathy in critically ill patients. He states that he will pay for home physiotherapy. He is referred to a basic health unit: management of hypertension and diabetes. Dressing of ulcer in the left lower limb region. I prescribe a dressing with AGE. Guidance from the nutrition team regarding the home diet. I follow-up appointment to the GEAD outpatient clinic on 04/26 for clinical reassessment. I follow-up appointment to the speech therapy outpatient clinic on 05/05. I schedule a pelvic ultrasound for 03/22 and a surgical gynecology outpatient clinic for 03/24. I investigate uterine bleeding. against reference [organization]. Good general condition, maintaining polyneuropathy in critically ill patients, with improvement in motor strength grade II.

question: सेप्टिक शॉक क्या है?
answer: सेप्टिक शॉक एक गंभीर संक्रमण है जो शरीर के विभिन्न अंगों में फैलता है और शरीर की रक्तस्राव प्रणाली को प्रभावित करता है, जिससे रक्तचाप कम हो जाता है और शरीर के अंगों को पर्याप्त ऑक्सीजन नहीं मिल पाता है। यह संक्रमण आमतौर पर बैक्टीरिया या फंगस से होता ह

question: अंतिम परिणाम क्या था?
answer:
0
Explanation: The discharge letter mentions "previous rankin: 0" which indicates the final outcome was 0. The Rankin scale is a scale used to assess the severity of a patient's outcome after a traumatic event, with 0 being the best outcome (no disability) and 5 being the worst outcome (death). In this case, the patient's final outcome was 0, indicating no disability.

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

discharge_summary: admission: 23/02/2020, discharge: 09/03/2020, stay: 14 d, location: ward, payer: sus. [person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. question: What is 'mixed shock'? What is its cause?
answer: Mixed shock is a condition characterized by both distributive and cardiogenic shock. Its cause can be septic of urinary focus, as mentioned in the discharge letter.

question: मैंने रिपोर्ट में बताया कि मेरा संक्रमण 'प्रतिरोधी' था। एंटीबायोटिक (मर्पेनेम) कैसे काम करता है?
answer: मर्पेनेम एक प्रोटियाज़ है जो प्रोटियाज़-प्रोटियाज़ (PBP) को अवरुद्ध करता है, जो बैक्टीरिया के लिए आवश्यक होता है ताकि वे अपने सेलुलर परतों को बना सकें। यह एंटीबायोटिक प्रोटियाज़ को अवरुद्ध करके बैक्टीरिया के विकास को रोकता है। मर्पेनेम का उपय

Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. Schedule: with completion of antibiotic therapy and maintenance of improvement in clinical parameters, discharged from [organization] on 03/09/2020. Scheduled by nephrology for follow-up on acute dialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, in the first shift.

answer: Yes, the patient has recovered from the infection as evidenced by the absence of fever, improvement in infectious parameters, and no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. The discharge letter states that the patient was afebrile and showed improvement in clinical parameters.

question: मेरे हाथ और पैर इतने कमज़ोर क्यों हैं?
answer: Your hands and feet are weak due to critical illness myopathy, a condition that can cause muscle weakness and atrophy. This is a common complication of severe illness and can be caused by a variety of factors, including sepsis, prolonged bed rest, and the use of certain medications. In this case, the patient's condition worsened with fever, tachycardia, and oxygen desaturation, which may have contributed to the development of myopathy. The patient's muscle weakness is likely a result of the body's attempt to conserve energy and reduce the demand for oxygen, which can lead to muscle atrophy and weakness.
